elements.content: A previously elusive “molecular capsule” and various other structural motifs incorporating p-sulfonatocalix[4]arene are accessible by controlling the pH and by varying the stoichiometry of the calixarene relative to potential guest molecules and trivalent metal ions. The “molecular capsule” has monoprotonated 1-aza-18-crown-6 shrouded by two calixarenes, which hydrogen bond to aquated lanthanide ions. In contrast, the presence of 1-aza-15-crown-5 forms a complex devoid of the crown ether, with lanthanide ions directly bound to sulfonate groups. Also reported are a coordination polymer incorporating monoprotonated 1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane in the cavity of one calixarene which forms chelate rings to lanthanide ions and the structure of a capsule with 4,13-diaza-18-crown-6 surrounded by two calixarenes which hydrogen bond to homoleptic aquated trivalent gallium ions.

elements.content: The chemistry of water-soluble calixarenes is extensive and has been widely studied due to their ability to form a vast range of intermolecular interactions. In addition, they also show a wide variety of inclusion properties and metal coordination to both main group and lanthanide metal ions. We have focused much attention on the supramolecular chemistry of the water-soluble p-sulfonatocalix[n]arenes, in particular, that of p-sulfonatocalix[4]arene in its penta- and tetra-anionic species as well as conjugate acids. Supramolecular architectures that incorporate p-sulfonatocalix[4]arene as a host container molecule typically adopt an antiparallel bilayer arrangement. Such assemblies maximize hydrophobic−hydrophobic and hydrophilic−hydrophilic interactions typically through aromatic π-interactions and hydrogen bonding from sulfonate or hydroxyl groups to solvent water molecules within bilayers. The calixarene is versatile in its ability to accommodate a range of molecules of different sizes and shapes in the solid state. This is possible, in part, by subtle changes in the shape of the cone conformation, notably, the splaying apart of opposite phenol rings. Some noteworthy examples of such host−guest chemistry of p-sulfonatocalix[4]arene are the inclusion of large globular like guests such as [2.2.2]cryptand and disc-shaped molecules such as 4,13-diaza-18-crown-6 and cyclam in the protonated forms. We have also examined the supramolecular chemistry of the same calixarene with amino acids and related molecules, as has Coleman et. al. Host−guest complexes with diprotonated 4,13-diaza-18-crown-6 crystallize rapidly in the presence of aquated lanthanide ions as molecular capsules at a pH < 3. This finding has implications in the use of p-sulfonatocalix[4]arene as a means of purifying (bis-)amino functionalized molecules such as (di)aza-crown ethers and cryptands through self-assembly processes, noting some of these molecules are precursors in mixed cis-platin derivates for use as novel anti-cancer drugs.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The chemistry of water-soluble calixarenes is extensive and has been widely studied due to their ability to form a vast range of intermolecular interactions. In addition, they also show a wide variety of inclusion properties and metal coordination to both main group and lanthanide metal ions. We have focused much attention on the supramolecular chemistry of the water-soluble p-sulfonatocalix[n]arenes, in particular, that of p-sulfonatocalix[4]arene in its penta- and tetra-anionic species as well as conjugate acids. Supramolecular architectures that incorporate p-sulfonatocalix[4]arene as a host container molecule typically adopt an antiparallel bilayer arrangement. Such assemblies maximize hydrophobic-hydrophobic and hydrophilic-hydrophilic interactions typically through aromatic π-interactions and hydrogen bonding from sulfonate or hydroxyl groups to solvent water molecules within bilayers. The calixarene is versatile in its ability to accommodate a range of molecules of different sizes and shapes in the solid state. This is possible, in part, by subtle changes in the shape of the cone conformation, notably, the splaying apart of opposite phenol rings. Some noteworthy examples of such host-guest chemistry of p-sulfonatocalix[4]arene are the inclusion of large globular like guests such as [2.2.2]cryptand and disc-shaped molecules such as 4,13-diaza-18-crown-6 and cyclam in the protonated forms. We have also examined the supramolecular chemistry of the same calixarene with amino acids and related molecules, as has Coleman et. al. Host-guest complexes with diprotonated 4,13-diaza-18-crown-6 crystallize rapidly in the presence of aquated lanthanide ions as molecular capsules at a pH < 3. This finding has implications in the use of p-sulfonatocalix[4]arene as a means of purifying (bis-)amino functionalized molecules such as (di)aza-crown ethers and cryptands through self-assembly processes, noting some of these molecules are precursors in mixed cis-platin derivates for use as novel anti-cancer drugs.

elements.content: The present contribution deals with some new structural motifs which are formed either as “molecular capsules” or coordination polymers in the presence of aza-crown ethers and either aquated neodymium(III) or gallium(III) cations. The formation of molecular capsules is a solid state arrangement of the calixarene and other components, and the issue of their existence in solution is being addressed elsewhere. The findings include the formation of a host−guest complex of monoprotonated 1-aza-18-crown-6, with p-sulfonatocalixarene in the presence of aquated neodymium(III) cations, which forms at low pH (<0.5) noting the prior exclusion at a pH ∼ 3. In addition, we report the encapsulation of diprotonated 4,13-diaza-18-crown-6 in a molecular capsule formed with aquated gallium(III) cations residing at the hydrophilic regions of the p-sulfonatocalix[4]arenes, thus demonstrating the ability of this system to assemble in the presence of dissimilar polyaquated metal cations. Two coordination polymers are reported, the first of which is two-dimensional with the lanthanide ions bridging adjacent bilayers generating a closed capsule arrangement within which water molecules are trapped in the cavities. The latter is also two-dimensional but with monoprotonated 1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane molecules residing in the cavities of the calixarenes which assemble into bilayers.

The findings include the formation of a host-guest complex of monoprotonated 1-aza-18-crown-6, with p-sulfonatocalixarene in the presence of aquated neodymium(III) cations, which forms at low pH (<0.5) noting the prior exclusion at a pH ~ 3. In addition, we report the encapsulation of diprotonated 4,13-diaza-18-crown-6 in  a molecular capsule formed with aquated gallium(III) cations residing at the hydrophilic regions of the p-sulfonatocalix[4]arenes, thus demonstrating the ability of this system to assemble in the presence of dissimilar polyaquated metal cations. Two coordination polymers are reported, the first of which is two-dimensional with the lanthanide ions bridging adjacent bilayers generating a closed capsule arrangement within which water molecules are trapped in the cavities. The latter is also two-dimensional but with monoprotonated 1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane molecules residing in the cavities of the calixarenes which assemble into bilayers.

elements.content: Molecular Capsule, [(1-Aza-18-crown-6 + H + )⊂[(H 2 O) 2 [Nd(H 2 O) 9 3+ ] 2 [( p -sulfonatocalix[4]arene) 2 + H + ]] · 27.5H 2 O, 1. The complex, 1, based on a molecular capsule arrangement rapidly crystallized from an acidic solution (pH < 0.5) containing excess p-sulfonic acidcalix[4]arene relative to 1-aza-18-crown-6 and neodymium chloride (eq 1). The use of highly acidic solutions was prompted by the previous exclusion of the crown ether from the capsule which was ascribed to the otherwise overall charge disparity within a potential capsule at a pH 2−3. At a pH < 0.5, the nitrogen of the aza-crown ether is protonated which in turn requires protonation of one of the sulfonate groups of one of the calixarenes in the capsule which is likely at such a low pH and which is based on charge neutrality considerations. Diprotonation of 4,13-diaza-18-crown-6 also rapidly forms an analogous capsule in the presence of lanthanide ions, but without protonation of any sulfonate groups given the dicationic nature of the guest. In effect, the capture of diprotonated 4,13-diaza-18-crown-6 is emulated with the mono-aza crown ether using a large excess of the p-sulfonic acidcalix[4]arene to facilitate both favorable protonation of a sulfonate group and charge neutrality for capsule formation.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

 Molecular Capsule, [(1-Aza-18-crown-6 +  H  +   )⊂[(H  2  O)  2  [Nd(H  2  O)  9   3+   ]  2  [(  p  -sulfonatocalix[4]arene)  2   + H  +   ]] ⋅ 27.5H  2  O, 1. The complex, 1, based on a molecular capsule arrangement rapidly crystallized from an acidic solution (pH < 0.5) containing excess p-sulfonic acidcalix[4]arene relative to 1-aza-18-crown-6 and neodymium chloride (eq 1). The use of highly acidic solutions was prompted by the previous exclusion of the crown ether from the capsule which was ascribed to the otherwise overall charge disparity within a potential capsule at a pH 2-3. At a pH < 0.5, the nitrogen of the aza-crown ether is protonated which in turn requires protonation of one of the sulfonate groups of one of the calixarenes in the capsule which is likely at such a low pH and which is based on charge neutrality considerations. Diprotonation of 4,13-diaza-18-crown-6 also rapidly forms an analogous capsule in the presence of lanthanide ions, but without protonation of any sulfonate groups given the dicationic nature of the guest. In effect, the capture of diprotonated 4,13-diaza-18-crown-6 is emulated with the mono-aza crown ether using a large excess of the p-sulfonic acidcalix[4]arene to facilitate both favorable protonation of a sulfonate group and charge neutrality for capsule formation.

The structure of 1 was determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction techniques with the crystals in the monoclinic space group P21/c. Part of the asymmetric unit consists of an entire capsule arrangement comprising two p-sulfonatocalix[4]arenes, one molecule of 1-aza-18-crown-6 (in the monoprotonated form), two solvent water molecules (one of which is disordered over two positions), and two nona-aqua neodymium(III) cations (Figure ). In addition, there are a total of 27.5 solvent water molecules in the asymmetric unit, some of which are disordered with partial occupancies of 0.5.

elements.content: Capsule arrangement in1 showing the distortion of the monoprotonated crown ether, and the polyaquated lanthanide cations (hydrogen atoms [except NH], one disordered solvent water molecule within the capsule, and other solvent water molecules are omitted for clarity).
elements.clean_text: 1  Capsule arrangement in1 showing the distortion of the monoprotonated crown ether, and the polyaquated lanthanide cations (hydrogen atoms [except NH], one disordered solvent water molecule within the capsule, and other solvent water molecules are omitted for clarity).

elements.content: Within the capsule arrangement, there is a noticeable conformational distortion of the aza-crown ether from the usual “crown” conformation, possibly arising from hydrogen bonding interactions to a water molecule located near the center of the crown ether (Figure ). This water molecule hydrogen bonds to two of the oxygen donor atoms of the crown ether with O···O distances of 2.844 and 2.879 Å. The protonation of the secondary amine in the crown ether results in intermolecular hydrogen bonding to the aforementioned water molecule with an N···O distance of 2.798 Å (corresponding NH···O distance 1.929 Å). Another hydrogen bond to this water molecule is also associated with a ligated water molecule of the closest nona-aqua neodymium cations residing at the hydrophilic rims of the calixarenes (equatorial region of the capsule, NdO···O distance of 2.724 Å).
elements.clean_text: Within the capsule arrangement, there is a noticeable conformational distortion of the aza-crown ether from the usual "crown" conformation, possibly arising from hydrogen bonding interactions to a water molecule located near the center of the crown ether (Figure ). This water molecule hydrogen bonds to two of the oxygen donor atoms of the crown ether with O⋅⋅⋅O distances of 2.844 and 2.879 Å. The protonation of the secondary amine in the crown ether results in intermolecular hydrogen bonding to the aforementioned water molecule with an N⋅⋅⋅O distance of 2.798 Å (corresponding NH⋅⋅⋅O distance 1.929 Å). Another hydrogen bond to this water molecule is also associated with a ligated water molecule of the closest nona-aqua neodymium cations residing at the hydrophilic rims of the calixarenes (equatorial region of the capsule, NdO⋅⋅⋅O distance of 2.724 Å).

elements.content: The second water molecule within the molecular capsule which resides on the opposite side of the crown ether to that described above is disordered over two positions. In the first position, the protonated nitrogen of the crown ether hydrogen bonds to the water molecule with an N···O distance of 2.909 Å (corresponding NH···O distance of 1.994 Å) (Figure ). In addition, the water molecule hydrogen bonds to two sulfonate groups, one from each calixarene with O···OS distances of 2.703 and 2.778 Å. The fourth hydrogen bond associated with this water molecule is from a ligated water molecule of the second nona-aqua neodymium cation with an NdO···O distance of 2.673 Å. In the second position, the disordered water molecule hydrogen bonds to one sulfonate group of each of the calixarenes with O···OS distances of 2.849 and 2.957 Å. There are, however, no other hydrogen bonds from the donor atoms of the crown ether to either of the disordered water molecules due to the aforementioned distortion of the macrocycle. The two water molecules which reside on opposite sides of the crown ether in association with the calixarene hosts, as in the diaza-crown ether example, collectively behave in a manner reminiscent to that of “Russian dolls”. This is related to other capsules with a sodium ion in the cavity of 18-crown-6 with two trans-ligated water molecules with similar arrangements of calixarenes.

elements.content: Both of the nona-aqua neodymium cations are in the tricapped trigonal prismatic geometry and have Nd−O bond lengths unexceptional relative to those reported for the analogous cation in the presence of toluene-4-sulfonate. Both cations hydrogen bond through one ligated water molecule to a water molecule within the capsule, as well as to the sulfonate groups of adjacent calixarenes. The four ligated water molecules which point toward the nearest capsule hydrogen bond to the sulfonate groups of the calixarenes (two to the upper calixarene and two to the lower in both cases) with NdO···OS distances varying from 2.646 to 3.065 Å (Figure ). In addition, two of the other four ligated water molecules (again similar in both cations) hydrogen bond to sulfonate groups of the nearest neighboring capsule (one to the upper calixarene and one to the lower in both cases) with NdO···OS distances varying from 2.698 to 2.969 Å.

elements.content: Projection of1 showing hydrogen bonding between adjacent capsules (hydrogen atoms, crown ether molecules, and solvent water molecules omitted for clarity).
elements.clean_text: 2  Projection of1 showing hydrogen bonding between adjacent capsules (hydrogen atoms, crown ether molecules, and solvent water molecules omitted for clarity).

elements.content: As is common with structures of p-sulfonatocalix[4]arene, the overall structure is based on the bilayer arrangement with π-stacking between the calixarenes, aromatic ring centroid separations of 3.497 Å (Figure ). Thus, the structure can be viewed as built up of bilayers which are positioned relative to each other such that the bowl of one calixarene from one bilayer lines up with a bowl of a calixarene from another layer, with the common cavity accommodating the aza-crown-ether. Alternatively, the structure can be viewed as built up from capsules which pack to form bilayers. The sequence of events leading to the structure crystallizing from solution for this system, and others, needs to be addressed by solution studies, an area we are currently exploring.

elements.content: The bilayer extended structure in1 with one space filling molecular capsule showing the extended bilayer arrangement.

elements.content: Within the extended structure, each adjacent capsule is skewed by around 90° to achieve maximum electrostatic interaction between the sulfonate groups and the polyaquated lanthanide cations (indicated by the alternating cation positions in Figure ). The numerous solvent water molecules reside in hydrophilic regions of the extended structure generated by the upper rim sulfonate groups and the base hydroxy groups of the bilayers, and which are presumably involved in extensive hydrogen bonding regimes throughout the extended structure.

elements.content: The p-sulfonatocalix[4]arene host molecules in 1 are splayed in one direction and pinched in the other to accommodate the guest molecule, as is seen when 18-crown-6 acts as a disc-shaped guest. The dihedral angles between the plane of the aromatic rings and the basal plane of the four hydroxy groups at the lower rim of one calixarene are 112.23 and 134.3°, while the other is splayed slightly greater in both directions with dihedral angles of 118.87 and 136.01°. This further highlights the versatility of the host molecule to accommodate a range of guests, a feature most strongly emphasized by inclusion of diprotonated [2.2.2]cryptand where the calixarenes are splayed equally in all directions to a significantly greater extent, a consequence of the globular nature of the guest molecules compared with the almost disc-shaped aza-crown ether.

elements.content: Molecular Capsule, [(4,13-Diaza-18-crown-6+2-H + )⊂[(H 2 O) 2 [Ga(H 2 O) 6 3+ ] 2 [ p -sulfonatocalix[4]-are ne] 2 ]] · 9H 2 O, 2. Complex 2 crystallized from a solution containing gallium(III) nitrate, 4,13-diaza-18-crown-6, and p-sulfonatocalix[4]arene (eq 2). Crystals are in the triclinic space group P1̄ with the asymmetric unit comprised of one-half of a molecular capsule which is one calixarene, one-half of the crown ether, one hexa-aqua gallium(III) cation (which is orientationally disordered over two positions and at partial occupancy 0.5), half of a hexa-aqua gallium(III) species (at full occupancy), and one water molecule which hydrogen bonds to the nitrogen donor atom of the crown ether within the capsule.

As for complex 1, there are several solvent water molecules situated in the hydrophilic regions of the extended structure. The capsule arrangement is similar to those previously reported by us for the analogous lanthanide systems, the difference being hexa-aqua gallium(III) cations residing near the upper rims of the calixarenes (Figure ).

elements.content: One of the hexa-aqua gallium(III) ions resides on a center of inversion with the ligated water molecules hydrogen bonding to sulfonate groups of the nearest calixarenes, GaO···OS distances ranging from 2.645 to 2.730 Å. The second hexa-aqua gallium(III) ion is disordered over two positions, over a center of inversion, and the ligated water molecules also hydrogen bond to sulfonate groups of the nearest calixarenes, GaO···OS distances ranging from 2.611 to 2.815 Å. Interestingly, in the Cambridge Crystallographic Structural Database, there is only one structural example of a homoleptic hexa-aqua gallium(III) species in the presence of a protonated secondary amine while also in the presence of two sulfate counterions, a smaller yet similar system to ours. One of the cations in the present structure has octahedral geometry with three ligated water molecules with Ga−O bond lengths of 1.954(4), 1.957(4), and 1.975(4) Å. The second cation, as stated earlier, is disordered over two orientations and has slightly distorted octahedral geometry and possesses six ligated water molecules with Ga−O bond lengths of 1.858(11), 1.885(14), 1.948(13), 1.950(12), 1.957(10), and 1.983(8) Å, all of which are unexceptional to those previously reported.

The second hexa-aqua gallium(III) ion is disordered over two positions, over a center of inversion, and the ligated water molecules also hydrogen bond to sulfonate groups of the nearest calixarenes, GaO⋅⋅⋅OS distances ranging from 2.611 to 2.815 Å. Interestingly, in the Cambridge Crystallographic Structural Database, there is only one structural example of a homoleptic hexa-aqua gallium(III) species in the presence of a protonated secondary amine while also in the presence of two sulfate counterions, a smaller yet similar system to ours. One of the cations in the present structure has octahedral geometry with three ligated water molecules with Ga-O bond lengths of 1.954(4), 1.957(4), and 1.975(4) Å. The second cation, as stated earlier, is disordered over two orientations and has slightly distorted octahedral geometry and possesses six ligated water molecules with Ga-O bond lengths of 1.858(11), 1.885(14), 1.948(13), 1.950(12), 1.957(10), and 1.983(8) Å, all of which are unexceptional to those previously reported.

elements.content: The diprotonated crown ether in the center of the capsule arrangement is similar to those previously reported for the analogous lanthanide systems with respect to the hydrogen bonding between the solvent water molecules held within the capsule; NH···O hydrogen bonding associated with two water molecules is reflected in the N···O distances, 3.061 and 2.709 Å (corresponding O···HN distances of 2.209 and 1.894 Å, respectively). One noticeable difference in the present structure is a slight rotation of the crown ether within the cavity, although the charged N-centers remain near the sulfonate groups of the calixarene, as expected in optimizing electrostatic interactions.

One noticeable difference in the present structure is a slight rotation of the crown ether within the cavity, although the charged N-centers remain near the sulfonate groups of the calixarene, as expected in optimizing electrostatic interactions.

elements.content: The phenol groups in the p-sulfonatocalix[4]arene pinch in a typical manner for this type of arrangement with dihedral angles of 108.18 and 130.71° which are unexceptional with the previously reported analogous structures incorporating trivalent polyaqua lanthanide species. In complex 2, as for 1, the calixarenes pack in the bilayer arrangement with π-stacking, with aromatic ring centroid separations of 3.58 and 3.83 Å (Figure ).

elements.content: 2-D Coordination Polymer, [( p -Sulfonatocalix[4]arene + H + ) 3 - (Nd(H 2 O) 5 ) 3+ ], 3. Slow evaporation of an aqueous mixture of excess p-sulfonic acidcalix[4]arene, 1-aza-15-crown-5 and neodymium(III) chloride afforded complex 3 (eq 3), which crystallizes in the tetragonal space group P4/nnc. The asymmetric unit comprises of one-quarter of a p-sulfonatocalix[4]arene container molecule which is bound to a neodymium(III) center sited on a 2-fold axis and disordered across a further symmetry site. The structure has a capsule arrangement as part of a 2D-coordination polymer and takes on a bilayer arrangement of calixarenes through CH···π interactions (CH···aromatic ring centroid distances of 2.90 Å). The most striking feature of this structure is this closed capsule arrangement formed by four lanthanide metals coordinating to the sulfonate groups of both the upper and lower calixarenes in each capsule (Figure ). This type of structural motif for the present calixarene is unusual given that the bilayers are typically separated by hydrophilic regions containing solvent water molecules, and which are usually separated beyond the ability of lanthanide ions to coordinate to sulfonate groups from adjacent bilayers.

Within the capsules, there is a large amount of diffuse electron density, which we were unable to model effectively as either a 1-aza-15-crown-5 molecule or disordered water molecules. Microanalysis of the bulk sample which had been ground, washed with cold water, and dried showed only traces of nitrogen (0.14%, cf. 0.72% for inclusion of the crown ether [calculated C:N ratio]). We therefore conclude that the diffuse electron density is disordered solvent water molecules trapped in the cavity. This is further corroborated by the NdO···ONd distance between the ligated water molecules which point toward the center of the cavity is 6.472 Å. Analysis of a simple structure on the Cambridge Structural Database which incorporates 1-aza-15-crown-5 and chloride ions shows the distance between opposite carbon atoms within the macrocycle to be typically 6−6.3 Å, without accounting for hydrogen atoms. Thus, 1-aza-15-crown-5 is excluded from the capsule, and this result is consistent with many attempts to form complexes of the crown ether with p-sulfonatocalix[n]arenes.

elements.content: In the present structure, the calixarenes have splayed equally in all directions with dihedral angles between the aromatic rings and the plane of the phenolic oxygens of 124.57°. A recently reported coordination polymer, which incorporates p-sulfonatocalix[4]arene and polyaquated lanthanide ions in the absence of a potential guest molecule, possesses similar dihedral angles. However, in the previously reported case, the lanthanide cations did not span the distance between adjacent bilayers and the structure revealed hydrophilic layers between adjacent bilayers with the calixarenes adopting a splayed conformation with dihedral angles of 125.6°. These dihedral angles are almost identical to those reported for the coordination polymer formed in the absence of a potential guest but in some way the presence of 1-aza-15-crown-5 in the solution from which the crystals of 3 deposited has presumably influenced the formation of the coordination polymer bilayers.

elements.content: The penta-aqua neodymium(III) cations are disordered over two sites either side of a special position (Figure ). Each of the cations coordinate to sulfonate groups from the four nearest calixarene molecules. In the present structure, pairs of calixarenes for each capsule adopt an eclipsed arrangement unlike that of complexes 1 and 2, which is likely due to the unusual mode of lanthanide coordination in this system (Figure ). It was anticipated that a low pH (∼0.3) would facilitate protonation of both the aza-crown ether and one sulfonate group in a capsule arrangement analogous to that in the 1-aza-18-crown-6 example, complex 1; however, this is not the case, and clearly other factors are important in forming any inclusion complex with 1-aza-15-crown-5.

elements.content: 2-D Coordination Polymer, [(1,4-Diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane + H + )⊂[( p -sulfonatocalix[4]arene) 4 - (Nd(H 2 O) 5 ) 3+ ]] · 4H 2 O, 4. In attempting to incorporate a wider range of bis-amino functionalized guests in the capsule arrangement, 1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane (DABCO) was added to the system in place of crown ether, notably, in the presence of an excess of neodymium(III) chloride in an attempt to favor rapid crystal growth as for the rapid capture of diaza-18-crown-6 in the presence of the analogous lanthanide species. The compact nature of the guest molecule has markedly changed the architecture of the supramolecular arrays forming an unusual 2D-coordination polymer in place of a capsule, complex 4 (eq 4). This coordination polymer, while displaying the typical bilayer arrangement, is unusual in that one sulfonate group is noncoordinating, and the overall structure further demonstrates the versatility of the calixarene to assemble in complex bilayer arrangements.

Complex 4 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/n, with the asymmetric unit comprised of one p-sulfonatocalix[4]arene, one penta-aqua neodymium(III) cation, one monoprotonated DABCO, and four solvent water molecules. Each calixarene is bound to three neodymium centers through two monodentate sulfonate groups (Nd−OS distances of 2.444(4) and 2.508(4) Å), and to the third sulfonate group through a four-membered chelate ring system (Nd−OS distances 2.496(5) and 2.780(5) Å). To our knowledge, this is only the second example of lanthanide sulfonate chelation with any p-sulfonatocalixarene, although chelation of an aryl sulfonate to lanthanum has been reported. The fourth sulfonate group associated with each calixarene however does not bond directly to any neodymium center within the coordination polymer layer, but does however participate in hydrogen bonding (Figure , which is discussed below). Within each coordination polymer layer, each neodymium center possesses five ligated water molecules that partake in an extensive hydrogen bonding network within the assembled bilayers (Figures and ). Three of the ligated water molecules point upward into the hydrophilic layer between adjacent bilayers, while the remaining two point down toward the base of a calixarene in the other coordination polymer layer within each bilayer.

elements.content: Each of the three ligated water molecules which point into the hydrophilic region partake in different hydrogen bonding regimes. The first hydrogen bonds to a sulfonate group within the coordination polymer layer (NdO···OS distance 2.747 Å) and a solvent water molecule associated with the adjacent bilayer (NdO···O distance 2.636 Å). The second hydrogen bonds to a sulfonate group within the coordination polymer layer, and also to one from the adjacent bilayer (NdO···OS distances 2.772 and 2.702 Å, respectively). The third hydrogen bonds to both a sulfonate group, and a solvent water molecule from an adjacent bilayer (NdO···OS distance 2.958 Å and NdO···O distance 2.720 Å).

elements.content: As in complex 3, the bilayers are devoid of π-stacking, being assembled in such a way as to optimize CH···π interactions between three of the calixarene methylene groups and π-systems of aryl groups from three nearest neighboring calixarenes (CH···aromatic ring centroid distances varying from 2.648 to 2.921 Å).

elements.content: An additional structural feature is that each calixarene cavity hosts a monoprotonated DABCO molecule which hydrogen bonds to solvent water molecules, as well as CH···π interactions from two methylene groups from one arm of the bicyclic compound to all four aryl systems of the calixarene (CH···aromatic ring centroid distances varying from 2.559 to 2.777 Å). The remaining two arms of the guest molecule point toward the adjacent bilayer in the extended structure, albeit with no additional CH···π interactions. Electron density located near one nitrogen of the DABCO was assigned as hydrogen, fixed in position, and is consistent with hydrogen bonding to the nearest solvent water molecule, N···O distance of 2.717 Å (corresponding NH···O distance of 1.825 Å). The same water molecule also hydrogen bonds to sulfonate groups from both the calixarene hosting the DABCO molecule and the nearest adjacent sulfonate group within the coordination polymer layer, O···OS distances 2.832 and 3.087 Å, respectively (Figure ).

The anticipated capsule arrangement including diprotonated DABCO was not formed under the conditions studied. In retrospect, this is consistent with monoprotonated DABCO snugly fitting almost completely within the cavity of a single p-sulfonatocalix[4]arene molecule, and thus is not protruding sufficiently from the cavity to bind to a second calixarene (Figures and ). While DABCO is bicyclic as for [2.2.2]cryptand, it is indeed considerably smaller than [2.2.2]cryptand and related aza-crown ethers which predetermine molecular capsule formation for inclusion of such a guest molecule. In the present structure, the dihedral angles defining the shape of the cavity of the calixarene are 114.75 and 121.79°, with considerably less splaying relative to those for [2.2.2]cryptand (128.85°). This is in contrast to a greater degree of splaying typically seen when disc-shaped crown ethers are incorporated. It would appear that by greatly reducing the size of the guest, the calixarenes, while in the bilayer motif, arrange themselves to accommodate the guest through varied interactions including CH···π, hydrogen bonding, and sulfonate−lanthanide chelation.

elements.content: The encapsulation of 4,13-diaza-18-crown-6 in the presence of p-sulfonatocalix[4]arene and a lanthanide(III) chloride (M3+ = Ce, Nd, Eu, Gd) is effected by a large excess of the metal chloride with respect to both the calixarene and the crown ether. Similarly, crystal growth in the capture of diprotonated [2.2.2]cryptand in coordination polymer layers is also effected by an excess of the lanthanide(III) chloride (M3+ = Ce, Nd, Sm, Eu). In contrast, the trapping of 1-aza-18-crown-6 in capsules is entirely pH dependent with two different complexes resulting from different acidities, coupled with varying the stoichiometric amount of the p-sulfonatocalix[4]arene in its acid form. Overall, we have shown that the system is versatile in hosting various (bis)amino functionalized (bi)cyclic guest molecules in their varied degrees of protonation. We have also furthered demonstrated our ability to control the assembly systems with p-sulfonatocalix[4]arene as a host container molecule by controlling pH with either the incorporation or exclusion of several (bis)amino functionalized guest molecules in the presence of lanthanide metal cations. In summation, p-sulfonatocalix[4]arene is a versatile host molecule which readily forms several supramolecular motifs, notably, molecular capsules, in the presence of (bi)cyclic amino functionalized molecules with crystallization occurring in some cases in 15−30 min. This knowledge may prove useful in the purification of such molecules in addition to understanding the effects of pH control within these systems which may aid incorporation of such guest molecules along with their hosts in larger supramolecular arrays, such as those reported by Atwood et al., notably, spheroidal and tubular arrays.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

The encapsulation of 4,13-diaza-18-crown-6 in the presence of p-sulfonatocalix[4]arene and a lanthanide(III) chloride (M3+ = Ce, Nd, Eu, Gd) is effected by a large excess of the metal chloride with respect to both the calixarene and the crown ether. Similarly, crystal growth in the capture of diprotonated [2.2.2]cryptand in coordination polymer layers is also effected by an excess of the lanthanide(III) chloride (M3+ = Ce, Nd, Sm, Eu). In contrast, the trapping of 1-aza-18-crown-6 in capsules is entirely pH dependent with two different complexes resulting from different acidities, coupled with varying the stoichiometric amount of the p-sulfonatocalix[4]arene in its acid form. Overall, we have shown that the system is versatile in hosting various (bis)amino functionalized (bi)cyclic guest molecules in their varied degrees of protonation. We have also furthered demonstrated our ability to control the assembly systems with p-sulfonatocalix[4]arene as a host container molecule by controlling pH with either the incorporation or exclusion of several (bis)amino functionalized guest molecules in the presence of lanthanide metal cations. In summation, p-sulfonatocalix[4]arene is a versatile host molecule which readily forms several  supramolecular motifs, notably, molecular capsules, in the presence of (bi)cyclic amino functionalized molecules with crystallization occurring in some cases in 15-30 min. This knowledge may prove useful in the purification of such molecules in addition to understanding the effects of pH control within these systems which may aid incorporation of such guest molecules along with their hosts in larger supramolecular arrays, such as those reported by Atwood et al., notably, spheroidal and tubular arrays.

1-Aza-18-crown-6 and p-sulfonatocalix[4]arene were synthesized by literature methods, while 4,13-diaza-18-crown-6 and DABCO were purchased from Aldrich and used as supplied.

Synthesis of (1-Aza-18-crown-6 + H + )⊂[(H 2 O) 2 [Nd(H 2 O) 9 3+ ] 2 [( p -sulfonatocalix[4]arene) 2 + H + ]]·27.5H 2 O, 1. p-Sulfonic acidcalix[4]arene (40 mg, 54 μmol) and 1-aza-18-crown-6 (8 mg, 30 μmol) were dissolved in distilled water (1 cm3) prior to addition of neodymium(III) chloride (10 mg, 40 μmol). On standing, purple crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction studies formed over 15 min (53 mg, 61%).

elements.content: X-ray Crystallography. X-ray data for all compounds was collected on a Nonius KappaCCD diffractometer. Details of data collection and structure refinement are given in Table . CCDC reference nos. 206291−206294 for structures 1−4, respectively. Crystallographic information files can be obtained free of charge at www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/conts/retrieving.html or from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, 12 Union Rd, Cambridge, CB2 IEZ, UK; fax (international):  +44−1223/336−033; e-mail:  deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk. Some solvent water molecules in compounds 1 and 2 were refined isotropically, and residual electron density in both compounds is associated with disordered metal cations. The routine SQUEEZE was applied to the data for compound 3 due to diffuse electron density that could not be adequately modeled as disordered solvent. This lowered the R 1 factor from 0.1730 to 0.1360. Residual electron density in compound 4 is located <1 Å from the neodymium metal center. All hydrogen atoms were fixed in geometrically calculated positions aside from the N−H of DABCO in compound 4, which was located in the difference map and refined with restraints on the N−H bond length. All crystals were susceptible to solvent loss, thus making bulk sample analysis difficult.
